verses.text: Satan rose up against Israel and provoked David to count Israel.
verses.comment: Chronicles names Satan as the instigator, while 2 Samuel credits the LORD. This shows a change in theological understanding over time.

verses.text: David said to Joab and the commanders of the army, 'Go, count Israel from Beersheba to Dan, and bring me the report so I may know their number.'
verses.comment: Beersheba to Dan marks the southern and northern borders of Israel.

verses.text: Joab answered, 'May the LORD multiply his people a hundred times! My lord the king, are they not all servants of my lord? Why does my lord want to do this? Why should he cause guilt to Israel?'
verses.comment: Joab is warning David about incurring guilt through the census.

verses.text: Yet the king’s word prevailed over Joab. So Joab departed and went throughout all Israel, and then came back to Jerusalem.
verses.comment: David insists, and Joab obeys despite his concerns.

verses.text: Joab gave David the total count of the people: all Israel had one million one hundred thousand men able to draw sword; Judah had four hundred seventy thousand men able to draw sword.
verses.comment: Numbers differ from 2 Sam. 24:9 likely due to textual transmission.

verses.text: But Joab did not include Levi and Benjamin in the count, because he was distressed by the king’s command.
verses.comment: Levi often exempt from censuses; Joab resists full compliance.

verses.text: God was displeased with this thing and struck Israel.
verses.comment: God’s judgment follows David’s action.

verses.text: David said to God, 'I have sinned greatly by doing this. Please remove my guilt, for I have acted very foolishly.'
verses.comment: David’s confession mirrors other psalms of repentance.

verses.text: The LORD spoke to Gad, David's prophet, saying,
verses.comment: Gad is called David’s seer/prophet.

verses.text: 'Go and tell David, "This is what the LORD says: I am offering you three options; choose one for Me to do to you."'
verses.comment: God gives David a choice as judgment.

verses.text: So Gad went to David and said, 'This is what the LORD says. Choose for yourself:
verses.comment: Gad delivers God’s message directly.

verses.text: Either three years of famine, or three months of being swept away before your enemies while they overtake you by sword, or three days of the LORD’s sword—a plague in the land, with the angel of the LORD bringing destruction throughout all Israel. Now decide how I should answer the One who sent me.'
verses.comment: Chronicles differs from Samuel, offering three years of famine (Samuel gives seven).

verses.text: David said to Gad, 'I am in great distress. Let me fall into the hand of the LORD, for His mercy is great; but do not let me fall into the hand of man.'
verses.comment: David chooses divine judgment over human enemies.

verses.text: So the LORD sent a plague on Israel, and seventy thousand men died.
verses.comment: Exact number matches Samuel.

verses.text: God sent an angel to Jerusalem to destroy it. But when He saw the destruction, the LORD relented from the disaster and said to the angel destroying, 'Enough! Withdraw your hand.' The angel of the LORD was then standing by the threshing floor of Ornan the Jebusite.
verses.comment: God relents at Ornan’s threshing floor, later the temple site.

verses.text: David raised his eyes and saw the angel of the LORD standing between earth and heaven, with a drawn sword in his hand stretched out over Jerusalem. David and the elders, dressed in sackcloth, fell facedown.
verses.comment: Angel’s appearance here is vivid and threatening.

verses.text: David said to God, 'Wasn’t it I who commanded the people to be counted? I am the one who has sinned and done evil. These are just sheep; what have they done? LORD my God, let Your hand be against me and my father’s house, but not against Your people, that they should suffer.'
verses.comment: David intercedes for the people, taking responsibility.

verses.text: Then the angel of the LORD commanded Gad to tell David to go up and build an altar to the LORD on the threshing floor of Ornan the Jebusite.
verses.comment: Site becomes location of Solomon’s temple. Ornan is Araunah in other texts.

verses.text: So David went up, obeying the word that Gad spoke in the name of the LORD.
verses.comment: David responds in obedience.

verses.text: Ornan turned and saw the angel. His four sons who were with him hid themselves, but Ornan kept threshing wheat.
verses.comment: Ornan witnesses the angel, showing the fear and awe.

verses.text: As David approached, Ornan looked up and saw David, and came out from the threshing floor and bowed before David with his face to the ground.
verses.comment: Ornan shows respect to David.

verses.text: David said to Ornan, 'Give me the threshing floor so I can build an altar to the LORD on it. I will pay the full price, so the plague may be stopped from the people.'
verses.comment: David insists on paying full price for the site.

verses.text: Ornan said to David, 'Take it! Let my lord the king do what is good in his eyes. Look, I give the oxen for burnt offerings, the threshing sledges for wood, and the wheat for the grain offering—I give everything.'
verses.comment: Ornan generously offers all necessary items for worship.

verses.text: King David replied to Ornan, 'No, I will buy it for the full price. I will not take what is yours for the LORD or offer burnt offerings that cost me nothing.'
verses.comment: David’s principle: worship should include real cost/sacrifice.

verses.text: So David paid Ornan six hundred shekels of gold by weight for the site.
verses.comment: Price is much higher than in Samuel, perhaps reflecting a royal purchase of the whole site.

verses.text: David built an altar to the LORD there and offered burnt offerings and peace offerings. He called on the LORD, and He answered him with fire from heaven on the altar of burnt offering.
verses.comment: Fire from heaven is unique to Chronicles, not in 2 Samuel.

verses.text: Then the LORD commanded the angel, and he put his sword back in its sheath.
verses.comment: The judgment ceases; angel's role in ending the plague.

verses.text: At that time, when David saw that the LORD had answered him at the threshing floor of Ornan the Jebusite, he sacrificed there.
verses.comment: This site becomes the future temple location.

verses.text: For the tabernacle of the LORD, which Moses made in the wilderness, and the altar of burnt offering were at that time at the high place at Gibeon.
verses.comment: Explains why David sacrificed at Ornan’s site instead of the Gibeon tabernacle.

verses.text: But David could not go before it to seek God, because he was afraid of the sword of the angel of the LORD.
verses.comment: David’s fear keeps him from worshipping at Gibeon.
